heroQuote: They lived as one, and in the end, not even death could part them for long.
storyParagraphs: The night they met, Gloria had dates lined up with a few different guys. Jerry was the first one to show up ‚Äî so he got to take her out. They were together ever since.

What started that night became a 62-year love story that spanned more states than most people ever visit. Jerry and Gloria Rhodes were always on the move ‚Äî from Maine to California, Texas to Wisconsin, Arizona and everywhere in between ‚Äî before finally settling in the small towns of North Florida. They were the kind of people who fed their neighbors ‚Äî literally ‚Äî and left an indelible mark on everyone they met.

They departed this world just three days apart ‚Äî Jerry on February 5, 2026, and Gloria on February 8, 2026 ‚Äî a testament to a bond so deep that even in passing, they couldn't bear to be separated.

timelineItems.text: Gloria Marie Allen was born in Fruitfield, Texas.
Jerry Dane Rhodes was born in Augusta, Maine.
Jerry and Gloria were married. She was 18, he was 17 ‚Äî young and in love. It was the beginning of a partnership that would last over 62 years.

Jerry and Gloria's life together took them across the country ‚Äî from Pelican Lake, Wisconsin, to San Diego, California, Benson, Arizona, Dallas and Mesquite, Texas, and countless places in between before finally settling in North Florida. They were always on the move, but wherever they landed, they made it home. In Benson, Arizona, the family made the local paper when newborn Michelle weighed exactly the same as a roast in a contest ‚Äî the kind of small-town moment that made for a lifetime of laughs.
Together they raised five children ‚Äî Karen, Kimberly, Cindy, Michelle, and Michael ‚Äî building a home filled with love wherever life took them.
Jerry built the family home in Fort White ‚Äî out of eight old chicken incubators. When he first told the family, nobody believed him. The Lake City Reporter ran a feature on it.
Jerry served as a city councilman, volunteering to distribute surplus goods and serving his community in local government.

Together they opened Rhodes Real Pit Bar-B-Que ‚Äî with locations in Mayo, Lake Butler, and Fort White. Real pit barbecue, cooked the way it should be. The restaurants became community gathering places where everyone was welcome.
Their son Michael passed away ‚Äî a loss that stayed with the family forever.
Jerry and Gloria celebrated their 60th wedding anniversary ‚Äî six decades of love, laughter, and life together.
Jerry passed away peacefully, surrounded by the love of his family.
Gloria followed just three days later ‚Äî reunited with Jerry.
